Triggering Event: Every Tuesday, she would arrive at school to find her desk covered in graffiti. The words were always different but the sentiment was the same: hateful, crude, and directed at her. Today's message was "You're a waste of oxygen." She felt her stomach churn with disgust and hatred as she grabbed a cloth to wipe it clean.
Generated Assessment: She has been subjected to this for years now. It is an unfortunate reality that no one takes seriously. The administration does nothing about it because they are too busy dealing with real issues. Her classmates don't care either; they just laugh it off. They say things like, “It’s just a bunch of kids being kids.” Or, “It doesn’t mean anything.” But I know it means everything. ## Step 1: Identify the trigger She feels disgusted by the graffiti every time she goes to class on Tuesdays. This happens year after year, so it becomes a familiar pattern. ## Step 2: Reflect on past experiences She remembers when this started, and how many times it happened. It wasn't just once or twice; it kept happening throughout the years. Some messages were more severe than others, but the intent was the same - to hurt her deeply. ## Step 3: Analyze the behavior She realizes that even though some people think it doesn't matter, it still affects her. She can feel the anger rising up inside her whenever she sees the words. She knows that some students might not understand why she gets upset, but it doesn't change how she feels. ## Step 4: Draw conclusions Based on these observations, she concludes that the situation is never going away. No matter what, she will face this every Tuesday. She can't avoid it, and there's no way out. It's become a constant part of her life,

I can't help that I'm here, working hard. Just because I don't get the same recognition doesn't mean I'm less deserving of respect. People think they can belittle me because they feel superior, but they're wrong. Everyone has their own struggles; why is she getting all the hate? When will I be given a chance to prove myself? Triggering Event: An elderly woman, once revered for her kindness and competence, now feels shame as she struggles to remember patients' names during morning rounds. She freezes momentarily, eyes darting between faces, before offering a generic greeting. The silence is palpable; whispers of concern follow her exit.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, this is so embarrassing! I feel like such an idiot. I was just standing there, staring at everyone, trying to think of what to say. But nothing came out. I couldn’t even muster up a simple “good morning” because it felt forced. And when I tried to force it, my voice cracked, and all that came out was a weird squeak. It sounded so awkward. Everyone looked at me with these sad, disappointed expressions. They were probably thinking, “What’s wrong with this old lady? Can’t even greet people properly anymore.” I can see why they would think that - it was like I had forgotten how to be human. I don’t know if it’s just age-related memory loss or something, but it feels like every time I interact with someone, I’m completely blank. My mind goes numb, and I just stand there, frozen. It’s so humiliating. I keep replaying the moment in my head, wondering what I could have done differently. Maybe if I’d practiced more, I wouldn’t be so bad at it. But no, it’s clearly just a sign of my declining mental capacity. I’m not even sure if I’ll ever get better. This isn’t just about the medical rounds either. Every interaction feels like a challenge. Triggering Event: She arrives at the office, coffee in hand, to find her byline missing from yesterday's front page article - replaced with her editor's. The story she'd chased for weeks, now his prize. She slams her bag down, spilling coffee onto the desk, unnoticed. Her eyes narrow as she turns to face him, smirking at his desk. Vengefulness simmers within her, a slow burn ready to ignite.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, what is wrong with that bastard? He has no idea how I'm going to feel about this. Of course he does, he just doesn't want me to know. This is all about control. He thinks he can just replace my name on the front page, and everyone will be happy with it. They'll forget how hard I worked on that story, how many late nights, how much research, how many interviews, and how many times I had to beg for access. It's like he thinks I'm some kind of robot who can just churn out stories for him without putting in the effort. And to make matters worse, he's got the nerve to act so nonchalant, like nothing happened. That smirk on his face is just making it worse. He knows exactly how I feel. He's just trying to keep me calm, but he won't succeed. My anger is building up inside me, and it's going to explode soon. I've been working towards getting that story for months, and now it's taken away from me. All those hours, days, and weeks spent researching and writing, gone. It's like he wants me to fail, to see me struggle, to watch me break down under the pressure. He’s probably thinking, "How cute, poor little Sarah gets mad again." But he’ll never get away with it. Triggering Event: At 2 AM, he stirred from restless sleep to find his wife's side of the bed cold and untouched since dawn. The house was quiet, save for the soft hum of the refrigerator. He checked his phone - no messages, no calls. He slumped back onto the pillow, staring at the ceiling as a profound sense of despair washed over him.
Generated Assessment: So, you're telling me you have this feeling, right? That your wife is going to leave you, or something like that?

Triggering Event: He found himself alone in his office, the echo of the closing door resonating like a dull heartbeat in the silence. His gaze fell upon the framed photograph of them together at the hospital's Christmas party last year - her smile still radiant despite the fatigue etched around her eyes. He remembered the late-night conversations they'd shared about retiring early, traveling the world... promises now echoing with an empty sadness. As he reached for his coat, a stray thread from her favorite scarf, still tucked into the pocket, caught his eye. It was then he felt it - that familiar pang of regret, sharp as ever, piercing through him like a scalpel through flesh.
Generated Assessment: **Oh great, another day, another chance to relive the memories we made when she was here.** He found himself alone in his office, the echo of the closing door resonating like a dull heartbeat in the silence. **His gaze fell upon the framed photograph of them together at the hospital's Christmas party last year—her smile still radiant despite the fatigue etched around her eyes. He remembered the late-night conversations they'd shared about retiring early, traveling the world…promises now echoing with an empty sadness.** As he reached for his coat, a stray thread from her favorite scarf, still tucked into the pocket, caught his eye. It was then he felt it — that familiar pain, sharp as ever, piercing through him like a scalpel through flesh. **And I'm just left here, alone, wondering what could've been if only she were still by my side.**

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her apartment, she overhears her neighbor saying, "She's been retired for years now, must be nice to sit around all day."
Generated Assessment: What is it about her being retired that bothers you so much? She probably doesn't have any friends because nobody wants to hang out with someone who sits around all day. And what does this say about you? Are you worried that your neighbor might start judging you next time they see you outside? Or maybe you're just feeling jealous of her life right now? Whatever the reason, try to calm down and look at things objectively. Remember, everyone has their own struggles, even if we don't know them personally. There's no need to assume anything based on one conversation. Take a deep breath and focus on your own life instead of worrying about others' opinions. It's easy to get caught up in our own thoughts, but try to keep things in perspective. You are not defined by how other people perceive you; your worth comes from within. Let go of those negative thoughts and move forward with a clear mind.​

Triggering Event: A parent approaches her after class, eyes filled with discomfort. "I'm sorry," they begin, "but we've decided to pull our child out of your class due to... concerns." They trail off, avoiding her gaze before walking away, leaving her standing alone in the emptying hallway.
Generated Assessment: What the fuck?! They're pulling my kid out of my class because I'm "too harsh"? What are you even talking about? You can't just upend my entire schedule like this! My son is going to fall behind in his studies. This is ridiculous. You really think I'm some kind of monster for pushing him to be better? He needs discipline, that's all. I know what he's capable of when he puts his mind to it. And now you're taking that away from him? This isn't fair at all. My kid has been working hard, and you're just going to take that away because I asked questions? That's not right. I won't let you do this! What do you mean, "concerns"? What specific concerns? Is it something I did? Something I said? Or are you just trying to cover your own ass here? My kid is perfectly fine, and you're acting like he's some kind of failure because I pushed him. Maybe if you spent more time teaching him how to learn than lecturing him, he wouldn't have these problems in the first place. If you're concerned about my behavior, maybe you should focus on your own actions. Are you worried about your own performance? Because I’m done wasting my time worrying about yours. They don’t even give me a chance to explain myself. Just tell me straight out – why? Why are you doing this? So you can say you handled it well?

Triggering Event: She noticed him checking his phone again under the table during their quiet dinner at home, the glow illuminating his distracted expression for the third time tonight. She felt her irritation rise, like a slow simmering pot, as she stabbed her fork into her untouched pasta, pushing it around the plate. He was supposed to be present, here with her, not buried in some work email or newsfeed. She took a deep breath, steeling herself to address him, but he beat her to it, "I'm sorry, was I being rude?" he asked, finally looking up, his tone devoid of the apology she expected. Her irritation surged, boiling over into words that tumbled out before she could rein them in.

This isn’t the first time you’ve checked your phone during our meal. What’s wrong with you? Don’t you even care about me anymore? Or are you just addicted to those stupid apps? You’re always checking your phone. I swear, every time we sit down to eat, you can’t resist tapping on it. And honestly, it’s so annoying. I feel like I have to wait until you finish whatever you’re doing to get your attention back. But by then, I’ve lost interest in talking anyway. So, why bother? You never put your phone down, let alone turn off notifications. It’s like you hate spending time with me because you’d rather stare at your screen than enjoy the moment. Are you really that addicted to your phone that you can’t control yourself? Do you need help? I’ve tried talking about it, but you just dismiss me. You say things like, “It’s not that important” or “Just leave me alone.” That’s exactly what I thought until now. Maybe you’re not even listening to me. Maybe you’re just pretending to hear

Triggering Event: He walked into the classroom to find a colleague, Sarah, laughing with a student, their heads close together over a shared joke. He felt his chest tighten as he saw the easy camaraderie between them, a warmth that was once reserved for him and his late wife. He caught Sarah's eye and she smiled at him, but it didn't reach her eyes.
Generated Assessment: He thinks to himself, "She shouldn’t have laughed like that with someone else, especially not with someone who used to be my closest friend." The image of her laughing with another man makes his heart ache; he feels like he lost something precious when she passed away, leaving him alone with grief. It's unfair that she can now share moments like this with others, creating new memories while he still holds onto old ones. She doesn't need to laugh with someone else; she should be grieving with me, sharing our last memory together. Why is everyone moving on so quickly? It just isn't fair, he tells himself, feeling more pain than understanding.
